Institutional baselines improved (respect for oversight, apolitical DOJ posture), yet Court doctrine and structural incentives from the 2010s persisted. Week 0 weights these durable architectures over goodwill. Difficulty 1.4 is sticky: norms can shift quickly, but doctrine, infrastructure, and political economy create drag on full repair. Week 0 leaves runway for four years of movement. Adjusted by decree and agreement to correct unrealistic baseline calibration.
traits.trait_name: Statues, portraits, and records of disfavored leaders are removed without process

traits.rationale: Presence is 7.6 (high) at the close of Biden I, reflecting improvement from 2020 without a rebuilt low‑risk baseline. Money‑in‑politics, concentrated corporate power, and path‑dependent industrial policy remained. Antitrust revival and pro‑labor actions nudged risks down, but the fiscal‑regulatory chassis still advantaged capital. Difficulty 1.6 is highly sticky: norms can shift quickly, but doctrine, infrastructure, and political economy create drag on full repair. Week 0 leaves runway for four years of movement.
traits.trait_name: Memory is curated by power—what cannot be controlled is erased

institutional_shifts: Congress: House Republicans push through a reconciliation megabill that rewires tax, welfare, and immigration enforcement, while embedding constraints on courts’ contempt powers—legislating structural inequality and weakening judicial leverage.

Courts: Mixed but pivotal role—federal judges block some agency dismantling, Harvard visa revocations, and deportations, yet the Supreme Court greenlights presidential firings at independent agencies and TPS termination, nudging doctrine toward a unitary executive.

Executive agencies: DOJ Civil Rights, CFPB, VA, FEMA, DHS, and ICE are repurposed or degraded—shifting from rights protection and service delivery toward enforcement, ideological policing, and austerity.

Media and education: Pentagon press lockdowns, legal threats against outlets, AI-driven content failures, and politicized curricula in Oklahoma show both state and private actors reshaping information ecosystems and civic education.

Foreign policy apparatus: Acceptance of a Qatari jet, politicized ambassadorial appointments, and racially charged South Africa and refugee policies signal erosion of ethical and rights-based foreign policy norms.
oddities_or_open_questions: The nuclear ‘renaissance’ executive orders promise rapid deployment and regulatory streamlining; it remains unclear whether safety and environmental review capacity can withstand simultaneous politicization of science and agency downsizing.

Corporate endorsements of a bill slashing SNAP by firms heavily branded around anti-hunger work (AT&T, Comcast, T-Mobile, Uber, United) raise questions about how business lobbying is being coordinated with the administration’s broader political project.

Judicial pushback on agency dismantling and deportations coexists with Supreme Court moves empowering presidential control; how lower-court resistance interacts with an increasingly executive-aligned high court will be crucial to future institutional resilience.
sensor.summary: This week delivers a concentrated surge of structural pressure toward authoritarian governance, anchored in three domains: a sweeping redistribution of fiscal power upward, aggressive weaponization of immigration and law enforcement, and a coordinated assault on independent institutions. Passage of the One Big Beautiful Bill and related budget maneuvers hardwire inequality into tax and spending structures, slash Medicaid and SNAP, and massively expand deportation and detention capacity, entrenching traits 32, 36, and 37. Simultaneously, the administration normalizes impunity for January 6 offenders while pursuing protesters, immigrants, and oversight-minded officials, deepening traits 4, 6, 9, and 41. Executive and judicial moves—TPS termination, dismantling of consent decrees, politicized appointments, and Supreme Court stays empowering presidential control over independent agencies—erode checks and civil service neutrality (traits 1, 14, 22, 38). Information control and narrative warfare—from mandated election lies in Oklahoma schools to press intimidation and foreign-influence scandals—further degrade truth infrastructure (traits 52, 53, 55, 60). Courts and some state actors do push back on specific excesses, but the net effect is a major weekly ratchet toward a unitary, patronage-driven state with stratified citizenship and hollowed social protections.
top_themes: Fiscal architecture as regime weapon: The tax-and-spend megabill, SNAP and Medicaid cuts, and immigration-fee funding model shift resources to elites while structurally disciplining the poor, sick, and immigrants.

Law as asymmetric tool: Mass pardons for January 6 rioters, RICO against protesters, selective prosecutions, and dismantling of police-reform decrees show criminal law shielding allies and targeting opponents.

Administrative state capture and downsizing: DOGE-driven agency gutting, VA and CFPB rollbacks, civil rights resignations, and court fights over independent boards reveal a concerted effort to politicize or hollow federal capacity.

Immigration as control and spectacle: TPS revocation, mass detention funding, deportations to unsafe or third countries, Harvard visa revocations, and racialized refugee preferences stratify legal status and normalize rights violations.

Information and education manipulation: Mandated election conspiracies in schools, narrative control from DHS and State, press restrictions at the Pentagon, and corporate DEI erasure degrade shared facts and civic literacy.
